Long-term memory.description: The ability to store and retrieve information over extended periods.

Encoding.description: The process of transforming sensory information into a format suitable for long-term storage.

Retrieval.description: The process of accessing and bringing stored information back into conscious awareness.

Attention.description: Focusing cognitive resources on specific stimuli.

Consolidation.description: The process of stabilizing memories over time.

Selective attention.description: Focusing on relevant information and ignoring irrelevant information.

Divided attention.description: Attending to multiple sources of information simultaneously.

Synaptic consolidation.description: Changes in synaptic strength between neurons.

System consolidation.description: The gradual shift of memory traces from the hippocampus to the cortex.

Cued recall.description: Retrieving information with the help of cues.

Familiarity.description: A sense of knowing something without remembering specific details.

Recollection.description: Remembering specific details about a past event.

Hippocampus.description: Brain region crucial for memory consolidation.

Cortex.description: Brain region involved in long-term storage of memories.
